metadata.case_name: Appellants v. Respondent No. 1 (Haji Mohamad, Haji Dada Wakf Trust)

facts.text: The suit premises consisted of a building known as Abdul Ratman Manzil and it belonged to Haji Mohamad, Haji Dada Wakf Trust.
The building was leased to Osman Jamal and Company under a rent note dated January 15, 1947.
In or about the year 1951, the firm of Osman Jamal and Company was wound up and the appellants took the premises on rent on a monthly rent of Rs. 320/-.
The appellants sub-let the premises while the Saurashtra Rent Control Act, 1951 was in force.
The Saurashtra Rent Control Act, 1951 was repealed on December 31, 1963.
The Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947 was made applicable to the area on January 1, 1964.
The respondent purported to terminate the tenancy by a notice dated February 12, 1964 on the ground of default in rent and sub-letting.
At trial, plea of default in rent given up; sole issue was sub-letting.
Trial court held contract of tenancy contained no prohibition against sub-letting and dismissed the suit.
District Judge, Jamnagar allowed respondent's appeal, held s.15 Saurashtra Act superseded contract, right to possession under s.13(1)(e), survived repeal.
Appellants filed revision in Gujarat High Court, Revision Appln. No. 371 of 1966.
Gujarat High Court Division Bench by judgment dated 2nd/3rd March, 1970 confirmed decree for ejectment, holding accrued right under s.51 proviso 2 Bombay Act.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the High Court was right in dismissing the revision petition and upholding the decree for possession on ground of sub-letting.

Whether the landlord is entitled to maintain a suit for recovery of possession under s.13(1)(e) of the Bombay Rent Act as applied to Gujarat on 31 Dec 1963, where sub-letting was during Saurashtra Act, but notice and suit after repeal.
Whether landlord had accrued right or privilege under s.51 proviso Bombay Act to recover possession despite repeal of Saurashtra Act without prior notice.

petitioner_arguments.text: Under the contract of lease, appellants had right to sub-let; respondent not entitled to possession.
No accrued right to recover possession without notice terminating tenancy before repeal of Saurashtra Act; notice under TP Act sine qua non.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Transfer of Property Act; s.51 Bombay Act

petitioner_arguments.text: Sub-letting before Bombay Act; s.13(1)(e) Bombay Act inapplicable as not 'unlawfully' sub-let post its operation.

respondent_arguments.text: s.15 Saurashtra Act prohibited sub-letting notwithstanding contract; superseded tenancy contract.
Repeal did not affect accrued right under s.51 proviso 2 Bombay Act; suit maintainable.
Even if no accrued right, at least a privilege to terminate tenancy survived repeal.

court_reasoning.text: Saurashtra Act s.15 unconditionally prohibited sub-letting; s.13(1)(e) entitled landlord to possession without need for prior notice under TP Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No notice required under Saurashtra Act to terminate tenancy for sub-letting.

court_reasoning.text: Right to recover possession accrued on sub-letting during Saurashtra Act; survives repeal under s.51 proviso 2 Bombay Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Accrued right upon happening of event (sub-letting), no further notice needed.

court_reasoning.text: Under TP Act, sub-letting not ground for forfeiture unless contract prohibits; but Saurashtra Act overrides, no notice needed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Landlord could not terminate under TP Act as contract allowed sub-let.

court_reasoning.text: Cited precedents distinguish accrued rights from mere expectations; right here accrued on sub-let.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Privilege to terminate exists but right to possession accrues directly under s.13(1)(e).

holdings.text: Suit for possession under s.13(1)(e) Saurashtra Act maintainable post-repeal based on sub-letting during its currency.
No notice under TP Act required; right accrues on sub-letting under Saurashtra Act and survives repeal.
Bombay Act s.13(1)(e) inapplicable as sub-let pre its operation.

precedents_cited.relevance: Provisions preserve specific rights upon events, not abstract rights.
Mere right to take advantage of repealed Act not accrued right.

precedents_cited.case_name: Director of Public Works v. Ho Po Sang
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinction between investigation of right vs. whether right exists; former preserved.

precedents_cited.case_name: Free Lanka Insurance Co. Ltd. v. Ranasinghe
precedents_cited.relevance: Inchoate or contingent right may be accrued if more than hope.

statutes_cited.name: Saurashtra Rent Control Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Prohibited sub-letting unconditionally; entitled landlord to possession on sub-let; right accrued survives repeal.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Repealed Saurashtra Act but preserved accrued rights; s.13(1)(e) inapplicable to pre-operation sub-let.

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Sub-letting not ground for forfeiture unless contract prohibits; no notice possible here.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding the Gujarat High Court and District Judge decrees for possession in favor of the landlord on ground of sub-letting during Saurashtra Act, as right accrued and survived repeal under Bombay Act s.51 proviso 2.
outcome.relief_granted: Decree for possession of suit premises to respondent No.1.

key_quotes.text: "the right of a landlord to recover possession on the ground that the tenant has sub-let the premises is an accrued right before the issue of a notice, if under any law it was necessary for the landlord to issue the notice to determine the tenancy on the ground of sub-letting."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Court rejects need for prior notice under TP Act.

key_quotes.text: "a right accrued to the landlord to recover possession under s.13(1) of the Saurashtra Act when the tenant sub-let the premises during the currency of that Act and the right survived the repeal."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on survival of accrued right post-repeal.

key_quotes.text: "It may be, therefore, that under some repealed enactment a right has been given but that in respect of it some investigation or legal proceeding is necessary. The right is then unaffected and preserved... But there is a manifest distinction between an investigation in respect of a right and an investigation which is to decide whether some right should or should not be given."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quote from Ho Po Sang explaining preservation of accrued rights.
